title: Leopard Gecko Feeding Guide: Complete Nutrition & Schedules
description: Comprehensive leopard gecko feeding guide covering age-based schedules, feeder insect variety, portion sizing, supplementation, and common feeding issues.
excerpt: Comprehensive leopard gecko feeding guide covering age-based schedules, feeder insect variety, portion sizing, supplementation, and common feeding issues.
author: Habitat Builder

content.title: Feeding Your Leopard Gecko
content.content: Leopard geckos are insectivores requiring a varied diet of live insects dusted with supplements. Proper feeding frequency, portion sizes, and supplementation are critical for healthy growth and preventing Metabolic Bone Disease.
Feeding frequency and portion sizes change as leopard geckos mature. Hatchlings require daily feeding while adults thrive on 2-3 times per week schedules.

rows: As many appropriately sized insects as they will eat in 10-15 minutes
Critical growth period; NEVER skip days
2 insects per inch of gecko length (e.g., 6" gecko = 12 insects)
Growth slows but still rapid; monitor weight
2 insects per inch of gecko length
Nearing adult size; adjust feeding to maintain healthy weight
2 insects per inch of gecko length
Fully grown; focus on maintaining body condition, not growth
Higher nutritional demands from egg production

content.content: Overfeeding is Common: Adult leopard geckos can become obese from too-frequent feeding. Plump tail is normal, but excessive fat deposits in armpits or belly indicates overfeeding. Adjust frequency or portion sizes if gecko becomes obese.
Portion Sizing Rule: Feed 2 appropriately sized insects per inch of gecko body length (excluding tail). Example: 8-inch adult = 16 medium crickets or 12 large dubia roaches every 3-4 days.
Variety is essential for balanced nutrition. Rotate between at least 3-4 different feeder types to prevent nutritional deficiencies. No single insect provides complete nutrition.

rows: Smaller than space between gecko's eyes
Gut-load 24hr before feeding; remove uneaten crickets (bite geckos)
High protein, moderate fat; excellent staple
Cannot climb glass; quiet; longer lifespan than crickets; harder shell than crickets
Similar to dubias; slightly higher moisture
Legal in Florida (where dubias banned); slower breeding
High calcium (natural Ca:P ratio); lower protein
Excellent calcium source; reduces supplementation needs slightly
High fat, lower protein; treat food
Offer in dish (cannot escape); high chitin content (hard to digest in excess)
Very high fat; occasional treat only
Can bite geckos; supervise feeding; NOT for juveniles
High moisture, low fat; excellent hydration source
Expensive; grows fast; good for picky eaters or shedding geckos
Expensive; requires fresh mulberry leaves or chow; excellent sick/recovering gecko food
Occasionally if sourced from reputable breeder
NEVER wild-caught (pesticide risk); must be captive-bred

content.content: Avoid These Insects: NEVER feed wild-caught insects (pesticides/parasites), fireflies/lightning bugs (TOXIC - fatal), boxelder bugs, or any glowing insects. Do NOT feed insects larger than the space between gecko's eyes (choking/impaction risk).

content.text: Recommended Feeding Rotation Example:

items: Monday: Dubia roaches (staple)
Thursday: Crickets (staple)
Sunday: Black soldier fly larvae (high calcium) OR hornworms (hydration)
Wednesday (next week): Discoid roaches OR silkworms (variety)
Occasional treats: Mealworms every 10-14 days as dietary enrichment

content.content: Leopard geckos require calcium and vitamin D3 to prevent Metabolic Bone Disease (MBD). The easiest approach is using an all-in-one supplement powder at every feeding.

content.text: Recommended All-In-One Supplements:

items: Repashy Calcium Plus LoD (Low D): Best overall option for UVB-equipped enclosures. Lower D3 levels prevent overdose when gecko synthesizes D3 from UVB exposure. Use at EVERY feeding.
Arcadia EarthPro-A: European equivalent to Repashy LoD. Balanced for use with UVB lighting. Use at EVERY feeding.
Avoid: Separate calcium/multivitamin schedules are outdated and increase risk of imbalances. All-in-one simplifies supplementation.

content.text: Dusting Instructions:

items: Place feeder insects in plastic container or ziplock bag
Add small pinch of supplement powder (1/4 teaspoon for 10-12 insects)
Gently shake/rotate container to coat insects evenly
Insects should appear lightly dusted - NOT caked in powder (excessive powder = gecko refuses food)
Offer immediately after dusting (powder shakes off insects over time)
Dust at EVERY feeding if using Repashy LoD or Arcadia EarthPro-A

content.content: Supplementation Critical with UVB: Even with proper UVB lighting, leopard geckos benefit from supplemental calcium and vitamins. UVB provides D3 synthesis pathway but does not provide calcium, vitamin A, or other micronutrients. Always supplement.
Gut-loading is feeding nutritious foods to feeder insects 24 hours before offering them to your gecko. The gecko receives nutrition from both the insect and its gut contents.

content.text: Effective Gut-Load Foods:

items: Commercial Gut-Load: Repashy Bug Burger, Mazuri Better Bug, Cricket Crack (most convenient and balanced)
Dark Leafy Greens: Collard greens, mustard greens, dandelion greens (NOT iceberg lettuce - zero nutrition)
Squash: Butternut squash, zucchini (vitamin A source)
Sweet Potato: Baked sweet potato chunks (vitamin A)
Carrots: Grated or thin slices (beta-carotene)
Avoid: Spinach (binds calcium), citrus fruits (too acidic), onions/garlic (toxic), high-moisture foods (cause die-off)

content.text: Gut-Loading Schedule:

items: Feed gut-load foods to feeder insects 24 hours BEFORE offering to gecko
For continuous colony maintenance: Always provide commercial gut-load diet + water crystals
Refresh gut-load foods every 2-3 days to prevent mold
Remove uneaten gut-load before it spoils

content.text: Dish Feeding (Recommended for Slow Insects):

items: Use shallow ceramic dish (1-2 inches tall) placed near warm hide
Best for: mealworms, superworms, black soldier fly larvae (cannot escape)
Pros: Gecko can eat at own pace; reduces stress
Cons: Not suitable for fast insects (crickets, roaches can escape)

content.text: Free-Range Feeding (For Active Insects):

items: Release dusted insects into enclosure near gecko
Best for: crickets, dubia roaches, discoid roaches
Pros: Stimulates hunting behavior; enrichment
Cons: Uneaten crickets can bite gecko at night - ALWAYS remove within 20 minutes

content.text: Tong Feeding (For Picky Eaters):

items: Hold dusted insect with blunt feeding tongs, wiggle in front of gecko to trigger prey drive
Best for: hornworms, silkworms, roaches
Pros: Ensures gecko eats; useful for sick/recovering geckos
Cons: Time-intensive; can cause dependency (gecko refuses non-tong-fed insects)

content.content: Remove Uneaten Crickets: Crickets become aggressive when hungry and will bite leopard geckos, especially during shed or at night when gecko is sleeping. ALWAYS remove uneaten crickets within 20 minutes of feeding.

rows: Shedding cycle (normal), temperatures too low, stress, gravid female (egg production)
Check temps (basking 94-97F), reduce handling, provide humid hide. If persists >3 weeks, vet check.
Dietary boredom, poor gut-loading of refused insects, previous negative experience
Try tong feeding new insects, gut-load thoroughly, starve gecko 5-7 days then offer only new insect type.
Temperatures too low after eating (cannot digest), prey too large, handled immediately after eating
Verify basking spot 94-97F, feed appropriately sized insects, NEVER handle within 24hr of feeding.
Parasites, insufficient feeding frequency, poor supplementation, temps too low
Fecal exam for parasites, increase feeding frequency, verify supplement at EVERY feeding, check temps.
Overfeeding frequency, too many high-fat insects (mealworms, superworms)
Reduce feeding to every 4-5 days, eliminate high-fat treats for 2-3 months, add climbing enrichment for exercise.
Food aggression (common), mistaking fingers for food
Use feeding tongs ALWAYS, never hand-feed, avoid moving hands quickly near gecko during feeding time.
Hunts but does not catch prey
Vision issues, neurological problems (Enigma syndrome if applicable)
Vet check for eye issues, tong-feed or dish-feed instead of free-range.

content.text: Winter Cooling / Brumation:

items: Some leopard geckos naturally reduce appetite in winter months (November-February in Northern Hemisphere)
Gecko may eat 50-75% less or refuse food for 2-4 weeks - this is NORMAL if gecko is healthy going into winter
Do NOT force-feed; continue offering food on schedule but do not panic if refused
Maintain temps and UVB as normal (do NOT reduce unless intentionally brumating for breeding)
Monitor weight - if gecko loses >10% body weight, consult vet

content.text: Feeding Sick or Recovering Geckos:

items: Use soft-bodied insects: hornworms, silkworms, black soldier fly larvae (easier to digest than crickets/roaches)
Offer smaller, more frequent meals (every 2 days vs. every 4 days)
Tong-feed to ensure gecko eats
Dust with supplements as usual - nutrition critical for recovery
Consider carnivore care powder (e.g., Oxbow Carnivore Care) mixed with water if gecko refuses insects - vet guidance recommended

content.content: Feeding Best Practice: Feed leopard geckos at dusk or early evening (6-8 PM) when they naturally become active. Avoid feeding during day (gecko is sleeping) or late night (gecko winds down). Crepuscular activity pattern = highest prey drive at sunset.
Keeping feeder insects healthy ensures your gecko receives maximum nutrition. Poor insect care = poor gecko nutrition.

content.text: Cricket Storage:

items: House in well-ventilated plastic bin with egg crate for surface area
70-75F temperature (room temp acceptable)
Provide commercial cricket food OR gut-load diet + water crystals (NO water dish - crickets drown)
Remove dead crickets daily (cannibalism and odor issues)
Lifespan: 6-8 weeks; order weekly or bi-weekly for freshness

content.text: Dubia Roach Storage:

items: House in smooth-sided plastic bin with egg crate
75-85F for breeding colony; 70-75F for maintenance (slows reproduction)
Provide commercial roach chow + fresh fruits/vegetables for moisture
Very low odor compared to crickets
Lifespan: 1-2 years; establish breeding colony to reduce costs

content.text: Mealworm/Superworm Storage:

items: Store in shallow plastic container with oats or bran as substrate
50-60F (refrigerator) for long-term storage (slows metamorphosis)
Room temp (70-75F) if feeding within 2 weeks
Provide carrot slices or potato for moisture every 3-4 days
Lifespan: 8-12 weeks refrigerated; 3-4 weeks at room temp before pupating
